sentences:
Le Dr Gordon Moore était le directeur de la recherche et du développement chez Fairchild lorsqu'il a écrit l'article, " Entassement de plus de
composants sur des circuits intégrés » publié dans le numéro du 19 avril 1965 de ÉLECTRONIQUE .

Non seulement les fabricants sont confrontés à un défi de rendement de densité de défauts qui a une corrélation directe avec la taille de la matrice, comme vous pouvez le voir sur le graphique suivant , les coûts fixes associés à la conception et à la mise en production d'un nouveau circuit intégré monolithique complexe ont grimpé en flèche avec les progrès de la technologie de fabrication.

Intel a une longue histoire de présentation plus conservatrice de ses nœuds de processus de fabrication, ce qui explique pourquoi sa densité de transistors à 22 nm est approximativement la même que celle de Fujitsu pour son processeur SPARC à 20 nm.  Alors que l'époque des microprocesseurs approchant la taille d'un timbre-poste est révolue, les progrès de la technologie de fabrication continuent de permettre une densité de transistors de plus en plus élevée.

Le programme va au-delà de l'exploitation des avantages de l'incorporation de nœuds de fabrication hétérogènes pour incorporer également des matériaux hétérogènes dans une conception de Chiplet.  (4) La magie de la loi de Moore était que le coût de fabrication par transistor diminuerait beaucoup plus que les coûts fixes n'augmentaient à mesure que la technologie de fabrication progressait.

Cependant, lorsqu'il est associé à la prophétie de la loi de Moore qui prédisait correctement que le coût par transistor sur un circuit intégré chuterait rapidement à mesure que la technologie de fabrication progressait, le moule du modèle commercial des semi-conducteurs a été coulé et les capitaux ont afflué librement dans l'industrie.

stories.title: La loi de Moore est morte - Vive le Chiplet !

en.body:
Dr. Gordon Moore was the director of research and development at Fairchild when he wrote the article, "Enhancing more than one of the most important things to do.
The 1965 ELECTRONIQUE , which was published in the 1965 issue of integrated circuits, was published by Dr. Carver Mead de Caltech as the "Moore Act" prediction. Very few people understand the essence of Moore's law or know the myth of tangent projections that Dr. Moore made in this article relatively short; they included personal computers, automatic orders for cars, communications equipment, and the  It was a very personal and many other innovations that at the time could have been seen as science fiction to some readers. Among Dr. Moore's projections for integrated circuits (CI), there was a 1975 economy that could dictate that up to 65,000 XNUMX components could be pushed on a single silicon pump. This took a few years more than projection, but the first 64-K DRAM (DRAM) of 64 Kos was released in 1977 with 65,536 XNUMX transistors on a "one-size-fits-all silicon pump." This is a remarkable projection since the first commercially viable DRAM was introduced in 1970 ; five years after the publication of Dr. Moore's article. The essence of Moore's Law Although there are a number of projections included in Moore's Law and almost all of them have been done to a reasonable degree, there are two projections that are "the gas" of Moore's Law. If we do a little computing, we can add color to these projections. Here are two quotations from the original article of 1965 and my extrapolation of the predictions. "The complexity of the minimum costs of the components has increased at a rate of about two factors per year. In the short term, we can certainly expect that this rate will continue to rise. In the longer term, the rate of increase is somewhat more uncertain, although there is no reason to believe that it will not be nearly constant for at least 10 years. This suggests that over the next ten years, we will see the density of transistors (components) increase by an factor of approximately 1.024 XNUMX. "In 1970, one can expect that the cost of manufacturing per component is only one tenth of the current cost." This provides that if the density of transistors (components) doubles each year, the cost per component will decrease at an annual rate of about 37%. This is important to understand, so let us take a moment to go through the calculations. With each doubling of the density of the components, manufacturing costs are increasing, but Dr Moore correctly expects that these higher costs will be offset by the annual doubling of the density. The result is a 37% reduction in net costs per transistor (component) which results in a 90% reduction in costs in five years and a 99% reduction in costs in ten years. Following this ten-year race until 1975, which worked very similar to Moore's law projections, Dr. Moore re-established expectations for a double-digit transistrant every 18 to 24 months compared to each year. Following these remarkable advances, if you live in the middle class or above the middle class in a developed country, there is a very good chance that you are a 'trillionary transit' - that with all the electronic tricks you have, you have more than a billion 1999. So far, we are - A case study When I entered the semi-conductor industry in 1976, the dominant DRAM device was the 16Kb (16K x 1) Mosttek MK4116 (Intel had 2116, but Mosta was the main supplier). Its electricity consumption (active state) was approximately 0.432 watts (432 mW). Due to the large size of boxes used in 1976, you could only install about 1.5 devices per square foot of printed circuit card surface (PCB). While I remember, the MK4116 sold for about $10 (dollars in 1976) in volume. (1) While DRAM 64Kb was out in 1977, its cost per bit remained higher than the DRAM 16Kb until 1980. If we extract this data, we can see that the typical 16 Go (16 Go x 8) memory used in the general public PC today would cost about $80 million for memory chips (400 million dollars in 2021), requiring a PC of about 300 million dollars, 300,000  35,000 square feet (more than the 3,500,000 0.10-square-foot hall at Grand Central) and would consume about 250,000 XNUMX power watts. At XNUMX $ by KWh, it would cost more than XNUMX XNUMX per month to feed this memory card. (2) To simplify things, all calculations are based only on the 8,000,000 4116 16 DRAM MKXNUMX that would be necessary to provide XNUMX Go memory. In addition to these, a myriad of additional passive and active components would also be necessary. These components are not included in any of the calculations. Today, you can buy a 16-go DRAM module for a portable computer in a retail store for about $40 (about $8,1975), or about the size of your index and consume less than 3 watts of energy. This is easily powered by a portable computer battery, but at $0.10 per KWh, the monthly cost would be a little over $0.20. Obviously, from so many points of view (cost, heat, size and reliability to name only a few), it would have been not only impractical, but literally impossible to build a 16 Go DRAM memory card in 1976. Of course, that would not have been useful. However, the microprocessors available in 1976 could only be sent to 64 Ko of memory. However, this illustration of the progress made by Moore's law since I joined the industry is only a case study that illustrates the path that industry has taken. If we adjust inflation, our data indicate that the progress under Moore's Act has resulted in a 99.9999995% reduction in costs (i.e. 30% per year for 45 years) and a reduction in 99.9999993% of energy consumption. And when you combine these advances with an even more significant reduction in the required surface, you can better appreciate what Moore's law has made possible, but above all, practical and affordable. If it is quite simple to exaggerate the progress made by semi-conductors that have reduced the cost of DRAM by bit by a factor of about 10 million, it is much more difficult to estimate improvements for processors. summations from industry that are much more intelligent than I have said that, considering the progress of the computing architecture that has been made possible by Moore's law, the economic efficiency of integrated processor circuits has improved from more than  A billion since the introduction of 4004 in 1971. . Although it is difficult to visualize and quantify these improvements with figures, it is very easy to prove that even a mid-range smartphone today has more computing power than the entire NASA had when the Apollo 11 mission landed astronauts on the same planet. in 1969. that next time you'll have a question in Siri, Alexa or Google... The economy of transistors There are all kinds of fantastic words you can use to describe various business models, but I like to keep things as simple as possible. In any business model, you can divide the costs between "fixes" (capital) and "variables" (marginals). If the model is heavily weighed by variable expenditures, there is little scale (the leverage effect) and profitability follows a fairly linear line with volume. However, if the model is heavily weighed by fixed costs, the model is changing (sortically) and profitability is rising significantly as the volume increases. For example, if you had to build oil, you should build a platform and make all the capital investment necessary to make oil (fixed costs), but once it is built and oil starts to flow, the costs to maintain this flow (the cost of the oil) will be (l) are very low. In this economic model, high fixed costs are incurred on the oil barrels that are pumped. The obvious conclusion is that the more oil barrels are produced, the lower the total cost per barrel (the fixed costs are reduced on more than one barrel of oil). The slightly less obvious conclusion is that the " marginal cost" of the next barile produced is very low. Since the marginal (variable) cost represents the total increase in the cost of producing an additional unit (bar) and no additional fixed cost is required, only variable costs are taken into account. Of course, given these data, the volume is important TRT in commercial models that operate with high fixed costs and low variable costs. This classic example of a high-cost/low variable business model is more or less aligned with what we see in the classic business model of semi-conductors. It costs a lot of money to open a line of manufacturing of high-tech semi-conductors (made in tens of billions of dollars today) and the design of a relatively complex integrated circuit for a high-end manufacturing process (5 nm) could easily cost a i-million. However, once the manufacturing plant is operational and the IC is in production, the marginal cost of manufacturing the next silicon chip is low compared to these fixed costs. The semi-conductor industry has a huge advantage over the oil industry; unlike oil where the final supply is limited (received reserves), there is a relatively unending supply of low-cost silicon (the basic material of most semi-containing  ) which means that there are strong reasons to keep prices down to stimulate demand and produce more volume. This phenomenon is demonstrated in the data. Bell Labs produced exactly one transistor in his laboratory in 1947 and it took several years before a catch was produced for limited applications. In 2022, only 75 years later, the semi-conductor industry will literally produce hundreds of billions of transistors for each man, woman and child on the ground and sell them in the form of integrated circuits for infinite fractions of one hundred. There are probably a number of stories behind the launch of this incredible trend towards growth, but one of my favorites was written by George Gilder in his book, Microcosme As history was told by George, Fairchild Symonicator sold a transistor (not only The amount of part 1211) in relatively low volumes to military clients for $150 each. With a cost of about $100, Fairchild has made a good profit. However, given the strict military specifications, there were still spare parts that did not meet the client's requirements. To find a home to these transistors, Jerry Sanders, who had recently been promoted to head the Fairchild general public marketing group, was charged with finding a buyer willing to pay $5 for the rejections. He found voluntary buyers, but in 1963, when the CCP required all new TVs to include UHF reception, a huge new market opportunity was opened. (3) Jerry Sanders then left Fairchild to start Advanced Micro Devices (AMD) The problem here was that even at $5, the 1211 general public version could not compete with the innovative metal-carrying tube of RCA called the Nuvist TV commercial, which was urs for only $1.05. Sanders tried all possible angles to circumvent the $3.95 price difference - the consumer 1211 could be directly fed to the PCB by avoiding the use of a Nuvistor and the transistor was clearly more reliable. However, he simply could not conclude the case. Since the potential television market in 1963 was about 10 million units per year; Sanders visited Fairchild's headquarters in Mountain View and met Dr. Robert Noyce at his home in the hills of Los Altos. He initially hesitated to ask for the $1.05 price he needed to complete the case, but once Sanders described the opportunity, Dr. Noyce accepted the application without delay and after a brief reflection, approved it. Sanders returned to Zenith and reserved the first consumer order of $1,211 for $1.05. To reduce costs, Fairchild opened its first foreign plant in Hong Kong, designed to manage the planned volume and, in collaboration with this, developed its first plastic packaging for the order (TO-92). Before that, all 1211 were packed as most transistors were at the time, in a metal box sealed with hermetically sealed (smelt metal glass) (TO-5). Once Fairchild activated production, he was able to lower the price to $0.50 and in two years (in 1965), he made 90% of the market share for UHF tunas and the new 1211 plastic generated 10% of the total profit. In 1965, it was also the year Dr. Moore wrote the article that was later called "Moore's Law". The lesson of transistor 1211 on how to effectively exploit the low marginal costs to increase volume was tangent in Dr. Moore's article. However, when it was associated with the propheticization of Moore's Law that correctly predicted that the cost of transistors on an integrated circuit would fall rapidly as manufacturing technology progressed, the half-conductor business model was have freely flooded the industry. Moore's Law in Processors: In 1968, three years after the publication of the Moore Act, Dr. Moore and Dr. Noyce, who were given the invention of the integrated circuit (CI) in 1959, left Fairchild to create Intel (INTC). They were quickly joined by Dr. Andy Grove, who, with his chemical engineering training, led the manufacturing operations at Intel. After Dr. Noyce and Dr. Moore, Dr. Grove was named the third Intel PDG in 1987. Intel began to manufacture static random access memory devices (SRAM) for central computers (the semi-conductor memory was part of Moore’s Law’s predictions), but quickly developed integrated circuits for displays and calculators, and was able to has passed from this to processors for general use. To optimize continuity, I will focus mainly on the evolution of Intel processors in this section. The first Intel processor, the 4-bit 4004, was released in 1971. It was manufactured using 10,000 2.250 nm manufacturing technology and consisted of 12 XNUMX transistors on an XNUMX mm. dier ( 187.5 transistors per mm ). Intel followed this one year later with its first 8-bit processor, 8008. He used the same process technology as the 4004, but with a better location and a better router, he had 3,500 14 transistors on an XNUMX mm. dieir (250 transistors by mm Intel launched his first 16-bit processor, the 8086  e x86 that continues to dominate personal computer and data center applications today. A year later, Intel launched the 8088, which was almost identical to 8086, but used an 8-bit external data bus, making it much more cost-effective to use in the first IBM PC. The 8086 and 8088 were made using a process of 3,000 29,000 nm and both had 33 XNUMX transistors on an XNUMX mm dier (879 transistors per mm ). What is not widely known or appreciated is that the 8086 and 8088s developed such a large design base outside the PC market that Intel manufactured the two integrated circuits until 1998. Intel released 32,80386 bits in 1985, which was manufactured using a process of 1,500,275,000 nm and with 104 XNUMX transistors and a NUMX size matrix (2.644x of all of this luminescence), which is all over the world. This is the first time I remember reading a Wall Street prediction that Moore's law was dead. It's been several years since I realized that Wall Street's views on the semiconductor industry were almost always false, but this is going into another story for another time... As the current Intel PDG, Patrick (Pat) Gelsinger covers in this related article: "Pat Gelsinger takes us on a journey in the past - and a vision of the future" Over the years, Moore's law has continued; sometimes they work more effectively than others, but consistently when they are considered in the longer term. To facilitate a little progress in the Moore's Law, the following table shows the PC processors manufactured on the different processes from 1,000 nm to 1989 nm from 2015 to 14. Since I don't have a reliable source of data beyond XNUMX nm for Intel , I stopped there. Processor An Process Production Table of Mother Transistor Count transistors by mm 1.000m 173 mm 1.2 million Pentium 800nm 294 mm 3.1 million-per 500m3mm 507 mm 5.5 mm 5.5 million 5.5 million 5.5 million 5.5 million 2.5 million 2.5 million  ion Pentium IV Willamette 180m 217 mm 42 million Pentium IV Northwood 130m 145 mm 55 million Pentium IV Prescott 110 110 112 million Moulin C65nm 90 nm 40 nm 40 400 400 400 400 400 400 m2 60 m2 400 100 m2 100 m2 60m2 7 000 100 m2 60m2 7 000 100 m3 112 million Mulin C 65m 90 nm 40 nm 40 400 400 400 400 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400 m2 400m2 600 m3 100m2 110 m2 65m2 400 nm 400 400 400 m3 100m2 100 m2 60m2 700 nm 400 nm 400 nm 400 m2 400m 40m 40m 40m 40m 40m 4 illions Pont Core i7 ivy 22nm 160 mm 1.400 million i7 Broadway 14nm 133 mm 1.900 million This table and the above data show that Intel increased the density of transistors (transitors by 4 0 000 m20 ) 40  its first processor (7) and its iXNUMX Broadway Core. When we look at integrated server circuits (on the contrary to only PC processors in the above table), we can see a significantly higher number of transistors and much larger stack sizes. Intel released its first processor at $2 billion, the 64-bit Quad-core Itanium Tukwilla in 2010 using its 65 nm process. With the large cache memory, the size of the matrix was 699 mm 2.86 million transistors per mm Intel then crossed the 5 billion-billion-dollar barrier in 2012 with the Xeon Phi for special use. It was manufactured using a 22 nm process on a mass of 720 mm of death (6.9 million transistors per mm ). It's the largest matrix size I can find for an Intel processor. Xeon Phi is one of the three monolithic processors I found that used a matrix size greater than 700 mm . The other two are Fujitsu SPARC VII manufactured on a 20 nm process in 2017, which used a huge 795 mm mmm (795 mm)  ), and the AMD (AMD) produced on a 14 nm process using a slightly smaller 768 mm die, but with the smaller manufacturing process, it had a much higher transitor density (25 million transversis per mm). The Oracle (ORCL) SPARC M7 was probably larger than Fujitsu SPARC VII, but I could not find matrix data for the Oracle processor. Intel has a long history of more conservative presentation of its manufacturing processes, which explains why its 22 nm transistor density is roughly the same as Fujitsu for its 20 nm SPARC processor. While the time of microprocessors approaching the size of a postage stamp has been revolutionized, progress in manufacturing technology continues to allow for a growing density of transistors. The highest density I can quantify today for a processor is the Apple (AAPL) M1-Max that has 57 billion transistors on its 432 mm die (131.9 million transistors per mm) and is made using TSM5 technology (TSM) and 131.9 million  The density of Apple M1-Max transistors is more than 700,000 4004 times that of the first Intel XNUMX processor, and from a technical point of view, it shows that Moore's double-digitity is still more than good; it is still not a good idea to A slower rate than before. However, while the density of transistors will continue to increase, two things have happened during the recent advances in manufacturing technology that it is important to understand. First of all, my contacts tell me that the increasingly low cost curve by transistor that was the economic engine of Moore's Law for more than 50 years began to sneeze after the 10 nm manufacturing node. This means that the days when the cheaper transistors compensate for the rapid increase in fixed costs to design and produce a new integrated circuit are at least counted, or even revolutionised. This means that if Moore's main economic engine is not dead, he is under respiratory assistance. Secondly, the data show that processors have moved away from the massive matrix sizes introduced between 2012 and 2017, and even the main processors such as AMD and Intel have adopted Chipplet strategies. In the case of Intel Ponte Vecchio, the design includes 47 Chiplts using a variety of manufacturing technologies. The king is dead, long life to the king! Deficiency of faults (D ) for a given manufacturing process is defined as the number of defects per silicon plate, divided by the surface of the plate, which are large enough to be classified as "torent" defects for the target manufacturing process. The problem is that, as the size of the manufacturing process (production point) decreases, the size of what is considered a “your” defect also decreases. In general, a stochastic defect is defined as a defect that represents 20% of the size of the manufacturing node. For example, a defect less than 9 nm can be acceptable for the 45 nm manufacturing node, but a defect greater than 2.8 nm would be defined as a "biter" defect for the 14 nm manufacturing node. For the 5 nm manufacturing node, a defect measuring only 1 nm could be a killer. This is one of the main reasons why it has become increasingly difficult to produce large integrated monolithic circuits (such as those measured in the juice zone) when using a cutting-edge manufacturing technology. . We can see evidence from the above data that shows that the size of the processors has culminated in the six-year period from 2012 to 2017, when the art state was moving from 22 nm to 14 nm. Memory devices, GPGPs, GPUs and some specialized automatic learning circuits (ML) are subject to the same performance challenges. However, in these integrated circuits, you will find billions of identical cells (functional blocks) that are literally identical to each other. To optimize returns, these integrated circuits that still use monstrosity matrix sizes are usually designed with reagent cells that can be masked or programmed to replace non-remitted cells. It is not clear whether this trend will continue. There is a variety of opinions about when the density of errors has become an insurmountable problem. However, according to what I have read, it seems to have entered the equation in the window from 22 nm to 14 nm, and under 14 nm, the data suggest that it has become significant, and beyond, a problem that would only get worse. Since an integrated large-scale well-sized circuit is more likely to have a defect within its borders than a small well; there is a reverse correlation between the size of the matrix and performance, and the trend will become even more contradictory to that manufacturing technology will move towards ever-increasing nodes. This problem was highlighted by TSMC during the second quarter when it was running test plates for its new 2020 nm manufacturing unit. Following these tests, TSMC indicated its average performance for a 5mm that was about 80%, but this performance fell dramatically to only 32% for a 100 mm death. As has been the case throughout Moore's Law, TSM has improved its performance since these first tests, but I am sure that the 5 nm yield is still less favourable than the performance at higher manufacturing cores and the trend is clear; the  large monolithic branches are revolutionized. Several years before TSMC published the first data on its 5 nm process, the AMD's DPD, Dr. Lisa Su, presented the problem of default density in a very simple graph at the IEEE International Electronic Devices 2017. Meeting (IDEM). This chart shows the cost increase per mm produced for a 250mm matrix size while AMD was moving from 45 nm to smaller manufacturing nodes. The under-estimation conclusion is that the increase in the size of the matrix becomes problematic economically, and once you fall below 14/16 nm, the cost is significantly higher. The density of errors is not a new problem - it has literally existed since the first day. However, the lessons learned have always pushed it beyond the current manufacturing core and the ability to solve the current core performance problems is what has guided Moore's law for more than 50 years. Although you can be sure that continuous efforts are being made to reduce the impact of the default density on the high-end manufacturing nodes, five reasons suggest that the Chiplet trend is not only there to stay, but that it is also about developing quickly and to allow new market opportunities. (1) There have been very significant investments in the Chipplets to reduce assembly costs and optimize performance. Although there are inherent penalties in terms of costs and performance when you move away from a single-purpose single-use silicone design, it seems that performance penalties will be minimized and cost penalties will be more than offset when the technology ie Chiplt will be fully exploited. (2) The Universal Chipplet Interconnect Express (UCI) has specified a deto-die connection standard to establish an open Chiplt ecosystem. The founding members of the consortium include: ASE , DMLA, Bras Google Cloud , Intel, Méta, Microsoft, Quantum, Samsung and TSMC . IUIe is similar to the PCI specification that standardizes the computer interfaces. However, UCIe offers up to 100 times more bandwidth, a 10 times lower bandwidth and energy efficiency 10 times better than the IPC. With this standard in place, I think we will see a fleet of new Chipplets arriving on the market. (3) With the release of its CHIPS Program (common Heterogeneous Integration and Intellectual Property Resus Strategy) in 2017, the Defence Advanced Research Projects Agency (DAARPA) was on the front line of the Chipplet curve. The objective of CHIPS is to develop a broad catalogue of third-party Chiplets for commercial purposes and military applications that, according to DARPA's forecasts, will result in a 70% reduction in costs and time for implementation of new concepts. CHIPS DARPA The program goes beyond the exploitation of the benefits of incorporating heterogen manufacturing nodes to also incorporate etherogenic materials into a Chiplt design. (4) Moore's law magic was that the cost of manufacturing by transistors would decrease much more than fixed costs were rising as manufacturing technology progressed. I do not find any data to quantify this, but I can find a broad agreement that the downward cost curve has been 10 nm high and that it is heading in a negative direction. As the cost of advanced manufacturing increases, a Chiplt strategy allows integrated circuit architects to target the high (cost) manufacturing nodes only for the Chiplt concepts that absolutely need the highest performance available to them. and target other parts of the Chiplet concepts towards low-power and/or low cost manufacturing processes. (5) The design of the pots may accelerate marketization, reduce fixed costs, reduce overall manufacturing costs for a particular design and take advantage of architectures that can be extended and/or modified over time. In other words, the Chiplt concepts offer unique flexibility that is not economically viable in monolithic concepts. This trend will become more apparent and will accelerate as we see the introduction of new Chipplets in accordance with the ITU. Not only are manufacturers facing a challenge of performance of default density that has a direct correlation with the size of the matrix, as you can see on the following graph, the fixed costs associated with the design and production of a new integrated circuit Complex monolithics have been smouldering with the progress of manufacturing technology. In other words, the data suggest that we have reached a bottom-up point and Chipplet is the answer; not only to the challenges of performance and higher costs, but also to enable the semiconductor industry to open up new market opportunities. Although I am focusing on this article on integrated processor circuits (mainly Intel processors for continuity reasons), the increase in fixed costs and the reverse correlation between yields and the size of the plugs also have an impact on the concepts of the e systems on the socket (SoC). There is already evidence that MediaTek will move to a Chiplit 3 nm design with TSMC for its application processor (AP) for smartphone and I am convinced that Quantcomm has a Chiplet design brass that he has not yet made public. With the UCI and the DARPA CHIPS program, manufacturers of SOC that target the wide range of markets beyond access points for smartphones will adopt tips to reduce costs, shorten development cycles and increase flexibility. This will open up new opportunities for support software manufacturers and a wide variety of IP companies. I believe that we will also see intellectual property companies expand their traditional market approach by taking advantage of the new IUI specification to “enforce” their known intellectual property (KGD) and effectively sell their intellectual property in the form of n that directs the manufacturers of semi-conductors and integrated circuit manufacturing companies. as well as OEM customers who develop their own specific chip for application. I think one of the most interesting things that the Chipplets will allow is the new markets that do not have the volume or are too fragmented to generate a multi-million dollar investment in a monolithic IC design. These include a wide variety of IoT, AI and Machine Learning (ML) opportunities where FPGA technology can be used for accelerators that can adapt quickly to changing algorithms and provide the flexibility of design to expand the market and the Life cycle SoC. The plugs can also allow new and existing SoC solutions to the new and existing markets by providing sophisticated processor solutions and other specific options to the client (add more processor hearts, adding an accelerator, adding more memory, even changing/ day the RF section for a new standard, etc.) . These types of changes and flexibility were virtually impossible with the concepts of integrated monolithic circuits. Bottom Line: Without the benefit of lowering variable costs (low manufacturing costs by transistor) compensates for the significantly higher fixed costs and increased fault density complications, Moore's law is reversed as we know it. However, as in the past, the semi-conductor ecosystem is adapting and as Chiplt technology gains ground, we will most likely be seeing a period of accelerated innovation and the opening up of new market opportunities as we move forward. The point here (the basic point if you want) is that the Chipplets open new doors to the creativity and the continuous expansion of technology in our way of living and working. We have reached a point where we no longer need to think only about what makes sense for the concepts of integrated monolithic circuits that are hampered by ultra-roasted fixed costs and extremely long delivery times; we can now concentrate on the Heterogen fibers that benefit from new open standards to optimize the concepts for the cost and final performance dictated by the use case. When you associate these new benefits with the standardization of the UCIA and DARPA CHIPS program, there is great potential for opening up new markets and new use cases that have not even seen the back of a cocktail napkin. en.title: Moore's Law is Dead - Live the Chiplt!

Someone with a lot of money to spend has taken a bearish stance on Oracle ORCL.
And retail traders should know.
We noticed this today when the big position showed up on publicly available options history that we track here at Benzinga.
Whether this is an institution or just a wealthy individual, we don't know. But when something this big happens with ORCL, it often means somebody knows something is about to happen.
So how do we know what this whale just did? 
Today, Benzinga's options scanner spotted 13 uncommon options trades for Oracle.



This isn't normal.
The overall sentiment of these big-money traders is split between 30% bullish and 69%, bearish.
Out of all of the special options we uncovered, 7 are puts, for a total amount of $1,014,868, and 6 are calls, for a total amount of $261,254.
What's The Price Target?
Taking into account the Volume and Open Interest on these contracts, it appears that whales have been targeting a price range from $50.0 to $70.0 for Oracle over the last 3 months.

Zacks Equity Research  ·  4-min read  Oracle ORCL recently updated NetSuite with the latest analytics and cloud capabilities
in multiple domains, including HR, supply chain, banking, finance and sales. This move is aimed at enhancing user engagement by driving efficiencies in businesses and making them more profitable. The innovations were announced at SuiteWorld 2022, held in Las Vegas, NV.  The highlights include improved accounts payable automation, a configure/price/quote or CPQ utility, and a mobile application that aids in packing and shipping.  NetSuite AP Automation embeds banking services into a cloud enterprise resource planning system to make it faster and easier for users to process bills and pay from the application.  NetSuite Ship Central is a new mobile application that helps organizations streamline and automate operations. It gives warehouse workers packing and shipping capabilities on a mobile device or kiosk.  NetSuite CPQ is aimed at helping sales teams quickly configure and price complex products by selecting from a menu of product features and applying customizable business rules. It's integrated with the company's Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), customer relationship management and e-commerce modules to allow pre-configured inventory and profitability data.  The latest SuitePeople Workforce Management helps organizations manage labor costs and profitability. The solution enhances employee engagement by automating routine tasks, such as scheduling staff, tracking employee hours worked and calculation of wages.  We believe that enhancing the functionalities of NetSuite with cloud-based capabilities places the solutions well to sustain their growing clout in the markets served by the company. Moreover, focus on customizing NetSuite to comply with local needs will boost global market reach.  Oracle Corporation Price and Consensus  Oracle Corporation Price and Consensus  Oracle Corporation price-consensus-chart | Oracle Corporation Quote  NetSuite Adoption to Favor Top-Line Growth  Oracle concluded the NetSuite acquisition in 2016. The buyout enabled the company to penetrate the small and medium-sized business market in the ERP segment, wherein it lacked a strong presence.  Notably, Oracle is benefiting from the ongoing cloud-based momentum. In first-quarter fiscal 2023, NetSuite ERP revenues increased 30% in the trailing 12-month period.  Per Gartner, price increases and delivery uncertainty, exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, have accelerated the transition in purchasing preference among enterprises in general, from ownership to service — pushing cloud spending to 18.4% growth in 2021 with an expected growth of 22.1% in 2022.  Per Fortune Business Insights data, the global ERP software market is envisioned to grow to $90.63 billion by 2029, exhibiting a CAGR of 9.1% during the forecast period.  The aforementioned reports favor the growth prospects of Oracle NetSuite. Markedly, Oracle has been named a Leader in the 2022 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Cloud ERP for Service-Centric Enterprises for Oracle Fusion Cloud ERP.  Management is elated that NetSuite is witnessing rapid adoption from retailers and non-profit organizations, among others. NetSuite AP Automation will initially ship with automated payment services provided by HSBC HSBC, although other banking partners are likely to be added in the future. Last month, HSBC launched variable recurring payments for open banking customers, and earlier this year, Oracle NetSuite announced a cashflow management service, Cash 360.  We believe the robust adoption of NetSuite, driven by new enhancements, will aid Oracle in strengthening its dominance in the cloud ERP market.  Besides, partnerships with Microsoft MSFT and VMware VMW are helping Oracle win new clientele. The company's share buybacks and dividend policy are noteworthy.  Last quarter, Microsoft and Oracle delivered a high-speed interconnection between Azure and Oracle's cloud to give Azure customers direct access to Oracle databases.  Oracle's partnership with VMware for Oracle Cloud VMware Solution has been gaining prominence, which is expected to have aided customer growth in the to-be-reported quarter. The solution has gained popularity among leading enterprises in retail, telecommunication, finance and banking, manufacturing, government and others.  However, this Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) company's higher spending on product enhancements, especially on the cloud platform, amid increasing competition, is likely to limit margin expansion in the near term.  You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.  Want the latest recommendations from Zacks Investment Research? The ex-dividend date of this dividend is Tuesday, October 11th. This represents a $1.28 annualized dividend and a yield of 2.09%. Oracle’s dividend payout ratio (DPR) is presently 60.95%.

Several research analysts have recently commented on ORCL shares. Credit Suisse Group set a $115.00 price target on Oracle in a research report on Tuesday, September 13th. Piper Sandler reissued a “hold” rating and issued a $70.00 price target on shares of Oracle in a research report on Tuesday, September 13th. The Goldman Sachs Group reissued a “sell” rating and issued a $75.00 price target on shares of Oracle in a research report on Monday, June 27th. Finally, UBS Group set a $75.00 price target on Oracle in a research report on Tuesday, September 13th. One analyst has rated the stock with a sell rating, sixteen have issued a hold rating and eleven have issued a buy rating to the company’s stock. Based on data from MarketBeat.com, Oracle has an average rating of “Hold” and a consensus target price of $88.67.

Oracle Corporation offers products and services that address enterprise information technology environments worldwide. Its Oracle cloud software as a service offering include various cloud software applications, including Oracle Fusion cloud enterprise resource planning (ERP), Oracle Fusion cloud enterprise performance management, Oracle Fusion cloud supply chain and manufacturing management, Oracle Fusion cloud human capital management, Oracle Advertising, and NetSuite applications suite, as well as Oracle Fusion Sales, Service, and Marketing.

Oracle's Ellison Offered Musk Billions to Fund Twitter Deal Like it Was Pocket Change
 Stock Markets  4 hours ago (Sep 30, 2022 12:28)  TSLA   ORCL   TWTR   By Investing.com Staff  Oracle (NYSE: ) Co-Founder and Chairman, Larry Ellison, was in the news today after just disclosed texts with Tesla (NASDAQ: ) CEO Elon Musk revealed he had nonchalantly offered to put in $1 billion to help fund the takeover of Twitter (NYSE: ), but later Musk asked him to put in $2 billion or more into the deal, which Ellison appeared interested in doing.  On April 20, 2022, Musk asks Ellison via text if he has any interest in participating in the Twitter deal. "Yes...of course," Ellison responded with a thumbs-up emoji.  Musk then asks how much he wants to put in.  "Roughly what dollar size?" Musk asks. "Not holding you to anything, but the deal is oversubscribed, so I have to reduce or kick out some participants."  Ellison responds: "A billion...or whatever you recommend."  Musk then suggests Ellison put in $2 billion or more.  "Whatever works for you. I'd recommend maybe $2B or more," Musk texts. "This has very high potential and I'd rather have you than anyone else."  "I agree that it has huge potential... and it would be lots of fun," Ellison responds.  "Absolutely :)" Musk ends the conversation.  Just a few days after this conversation, Musk entered into a definitive agreement to acquire Twitter for $54.20 per share, or approximately $44 billion. He later backed out of the deal citing Twitter's massive bot problem. The two sides are now battling it out in court.  Ellison is a past Tesla board member and has made billions investing in Tesla stock. The company has a market cap of $165.06 billion, a PE ratio of 29.21, a PEG ratio of 1.91 and a beta of 0.87.  Oracle ( NYSE:ORCL – Get Rating ) last issued its quarterly earnings results on Monday, September 12th. The enterprise software provider reported $0.81 earnings per share for the quarter, missing the consensus estimate of $0.88 by ($0.07). Oracle had a net margin of 13.15% and a negative return on equity of 161.07%. The company had revenue of $11.45 billion for the quarter, compared to the consensus estimate of $11.44 billion. During the same quarter in the previous year, the business earned $0.87 earnings per share. Oracle’s revenue was up 17.7% compared to the same quarter last year. As a group, sell-side analysts anticipate that Oracle Co. will post 4.12 earnings per share for the current year.  Oracle Announces Dividend  The firm also recently disclosed a quarterly dividend, which will be paid on Tuesday, October 25th. Investors of record on Wednesday, October 12th will be issued a $0.32 dividend. The ex-dividend date of this dividend is Tuesday, October 11th. This represents a $1.28 annualized dividend and a yield of 2.09%. Oracle’s payout ratio is 60.95%.  Oracle Company Profile  Oracle Corporation offers products and services that address enterprise information technology environments worldwide. Its Oracle cloud software as a service offering include various cloud software applications, including Oracle Fusion cloud enterprise resource planning (ERP), Oracle Fusion cloud enterprise performance management, Oracle Fusion cloud supply chain and manufacturing management, Oracle Fusion cloud human capital management, Oracle Advertising, and NetSuite applications suite, as well as Oracle Fusion Sales, Service, and Marketing.

Tower Bridge Advisors grew its stake in Oracle Co. ( NYSE:ORCL – Get Rating ) by 0.2% during the second quarter, according to its most recent Form 13F filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission.
The institutional investor owned 308,883 shares of the enterprise software provider’s stock after purchasing an additional 629 shares during the quarter. Oracle makes up about 1.8% of Tower Bridge Advisors’ holdings, making the stock its 13th largest position. Tower Bridge Advisors’ holdings in Oracle were worth $21,582,000 as of its most recent filing with the Securities & Exchange Commission. This represents a $1.28 dividend on an annualized basis and a yield of 2.10%. Oracle’s dividend payout ratio is presently 60.95%. stories.body:
Oracle Corp.  BX Swiss - USA  NASDAQ Composite Index  S&P 100  S&P 500  Oracle ORCL recently updated NetSuite
 with the latest analytics and cloud capabilities in multiple domains, including HR, supply chain, banking, finance and sales. This move is aimed at enhancing user engagement by driving efficiencies in businesses and making them more profitable. The innovations were announced at SuiteWorld 2022, held in Las Vegas, NV.The highlights include improved accounts payable automation, a configure/price/quote or CPQ utility, and a mobile application that aids in packing and shipping.NetSuite AP Automation embeds banking services into a cloud enterprise resource planning system to make it faster and easier for users to process bills and pay from the application.NetSuite Ship Central is a new mobile application that helps organizations streamline and automate operations. It gives warehouse workers packing and shipping capabilities on a mobile device or kiosk.NetSuite CPQ is aimed at helping sales teams quickly configure and price complex products by selecting from a menu of product features and applying customizable business rules. It's integrated with the company's Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP), customer relationship management and e-commerce modules to allow pre-configured inventory and profitability data.The latest SuitePeople Workforce Management helps organizations manage labor costs and profitability. The solution enhances employee engagement by automating routine tasks, such as scheduling staff, tracking employee hours worked and calculation of wages.We believe that enhancing the functionalities of NetSuite with cloud-based capabilities places the solutions well to sustain their growing clout in the markets served by the company. Moreover, focus on customizing NetSuite to comply with local needs will boost global market reach.Oracle Corporation Price and ConsensusOracle Corporation price-consensus-chart | Oracle Corporation QuoteNetSuite Adoption to Favor Top-Line GrowthOracle concluded the NetSuite acquisition in 2016. The buyout enabled the company to penetrate the small and medium-sized business market in the ERP segment, wherein it lacked a strong presence.Notably, Oracle is benefiting from the ongoing cloud-based momentum. In first-quarter fiscal 2023, NetSuite ERP revenues increased 30% in the trailing 12-month period.Per Gartner, price increases and delivery uncertainty, exacerbated by the Russian invasion of Ukraine, have accelerated the transition in purchasing preference among enterprises in general, from ownership to service — pushing cloud spending to 18.4% growth in 2021 with an expected growth of 22.1% in 2022.Per Fortune Business Insights data, the global ERP software market is envisioned to grow to $90.63 billion by 2029, exhibiting a CAGR of 9.1% during the forecast period.The aforementioned reports favor the growth prospects of Oracle NetSuite. Markedly, Oracle has been named a Leader in the 2022 Gartner Magic Quadrant for Cloud ERP for Service-Centric Enterprises for Oracle Fusion Cloud ERP.Management is elated that NetSuite is witnessing rapid adoption from retailers and non-profit organizations, among others. NetSuite AP Automation will initially ship with automated payment services provided by HSBC HSBC, although other banking partners are likely to be added in the future. Last month, HSBC launched variable recurring payments for open banking customers, and earlier this year, Oracle NetSuite announced a cashflow management service, Cash 360.We believe the robust adoption of NetSuite, driven by new enhancements, will aid Oracle in strengthening its dominance in the cloud ERP market.Besides, partnerships with Microsoft MSFT and VMware VMW are helping Oracle win new clientele. The company's share buybacks and dividend policy are noteworthy.Last quarter, Microsoft and Oracle delivered a high-speed interconnection between Azure and Oracle's cloud to give Azure customers direct access to Oracle databases.Oracle's partnership with VMware for Oracle Cloud VMware Solution has been gaining prominence, which is expected to have aided customer growth in the to-be-reported quarter. The solution has gained popularity among leading enterprises in retail, telecommunication, finance and banking, manufacturing, government and others.However, this Zacks Rank #4 (Sell) company's higher spending on product enhancements, especially on the cloud platform, amid increasing competition, is likely to limit margin expansion in the near term.You can see the complete list of today's Zacks #1 Rank (Strong Buy) stocks here.This Little-Known Semiconductor Stock Could Be Your Portfolio's Hedge Against InflationEveryone uses semiconductors. But only a small number of people know what they are and what they do. If you use a smartphone, computer, microwave, digital camera or refrigerator (and that's just the tip of the iceberg), you have a need for semiconductors. That's why their importance can't be overstated and their disruption in the supply chain has such a global effect. But every cloud has a silver lining. Shockwaves to the international supply chain from the global pandemic have unearthed a tremendous opportunity for investors. And today, Zacks' leading stock strategist is revealing the one semiconductor stock that stands to gain the most in a new FREE report.
